keyword: Networking and Internet Architecture: Computer Science-Based Breakdown
1. Network Fundamentals
Network Topologies: The arrangement of different elements (links, nodes) in a computer network.
Bus Topology: A single central cable to which all network devices are connected.
Star Topology: All devices are connected to a central hub.
Mesh Topology: Devices are interconnected with many redundant interconnections.
Network Types: Different scales and types of networks.
Local Area Network (LAN): A network covering a small geographic area.
Wide Area Network (WAN): A network that spans a large geographic area.
Metropolitan Area Network (MAN): A network that covers a larger geographic area than a LAN but smaller than a WAN.
2. Networking Protocols
Internet Protocol (IP): A protocol for sending data from one computer to another on the Internet.
IPv4: The fourth version of the Internet Protocol, which uses 32-bit addresses.
IPv6: The sixth version of the Internet Protocol, which uses 128-bit addresses.
Transmission Control Protocol (TCP): A protocol for managing the sending and receiving of all data packets.
User Datagram Protocol (UDP): A simpler, connectionless Internet protocol.
Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP): A protocol for transmitting hypermedia documents.
HTTP/2: A major revision of the HTTP network protocol.
HTTP/3: The third version of the HTTP protocol, using QUIC for transport.
File Transfer Protocol (FTP): A protocol for transferring files between systems.
Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP): A protocol for sending email messages.
Domain Name System (DNS): A protocol for translating domain names into IP addresses.
3. Network Layers
OSI Model: A conceptual framework used to understand network interactions in seven layers.
Physical Layer: The hardware transmission technologies.
Data Link Layer: Responsible for node-to-node data transfer.
Network Layer: Handles packet forwarding including routing through intermediate routers.
Transport Layer: Provides reliable data transfer.
Session Layer: Manages sessions between applications.
Presentation Layer: Translates data between the application layer and the network.
Application Layer: Provides network services directly to end-users.
TCP/IP Model: A simpler, four-layer model used for the Internet.
Link Layer: Combines OSI’s physical and data link layers.
Internet Layer: Corresponds to the OSI network layer.
Transport Layer: Same as the OSI transport layer.
Application Layer: Combines OSI’s session, presentation, and application layers.
4. Network Devices
Router: A device that forwards data packets between computer networks.
Switch: A device that filters and forwards packets between LAN segments.
Hub: A basic networking device that connects multiple Ethernet devices.
Modem: A device that modulates and demodulates analog signals for digital data transmission.
Access Point (AP): A device that allows wireless devices to connect to a wired network.
5. Network Services
Virtual Private Network (VPN): A secure connection over the Internet between a device and a network.
Network Address Translation (NAT): A method for remapping one IP address space into another.
Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP): A protocol for dynamically assigning IP addresses to devices on a network.
Quality of Service (QoS): Techniques to manage network resources and ensure performance levels.
6. Internet Architecture
Internet Backbone: High-capacity data routes that carry Internet traffic across the globe.
Internet Exchange Point (IXP): A physical location where different networks connect and exchange traffic.
Content Delivery Network (CDN): A distributed network of servers that deliver web content to users based on their geographic location.
Internet Service Provider (ISP): An organization that provides services for accessing and using the Internet.
7. Wireless Networking
Wi-Fi: A family of wireless network protocols based on the IEEE 802.11 standards.
802.11a/b/g/n/ac: Different versions of the Wi-Fi standard, each with varying speeds and ranges.
Bluetooth: A wireless technology standard for exchanging data over short distances.
Cellular Networks: Wireless communication networks for mobile devices.
4G LTE: The fourth generation of mobile network technology.
5G: The fifth generation of mobile network technology, offering faster speeds and lower latency.
8. Network Security
Firewall: A network security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic.
Intrusion Detection System (IDS): A system for monitoring network traffic for suspicious activity.
Virtual Private Network (VPN): A secure communication tunnel between two or more devices.
Encryption: The process of encoding data to prevent unauthorized access.
SSL/TLS: Protocols for encrypting data between a web server and a browser.
9. Cloud Networking
Cloud Computing: Delivery of computing services over the Internet.
Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS): Cloud-based services that provide virtualized computing resources.
Platform as a Service (PaaS): Cloud-based services that provide a platform allowing customers to develop, run, and manage applications.
Software as a Service (SaaS): Cloud-based services that provide software applications over the Internet.
Content Delivery Network (CDN): A system of distributed servers that deliver content to users based on their geographic location.
Edge Computing: A distributed computing paradigm that brings computation and data storage closer to the data sources.
10. Emerging Technologies
Internet of Things (IoT): The interconnection of everyday objects via the Internet.
Software-Defined Networking (SDN): An approach to network management that enables dynamic, programmatically efficient network configuration.
Network Function Virtualization (NFV): The virtualization of network services traditionally run on proprietary hardware.
5G Networking: The fifth generation of mobile network technology, offering faster speeds and more reliable connections.
Blockchain: A decentralized digital ledger technology used for recording transactions across multiple computers.
